chunks.original_text: 砂篆一挥走神鬼，雷电霹雳动天地。 信知妙用古所无，犹未收拾归天衢。 月冷风清白鹤唳，宝婶飞霞远玉壶。 武夷散人好诗酒，昔者见君今番无。 题清虚堂 月移花影来窗外，风引松声到枕边。 长剑舞余烹茗试，新诗吟就抱琴眠。 酒酪初泼青螺髓，香篆常烧紫马鞭。 九曲溪头冲佑观，清虚堂裹有神仙。 初见懒翁诗 一掬精神迥出尘，懒翕自是不凡人。 渊明松菊径犹绿，灵运池塘草正春。 已把芝田栽枸杞，不将苔砌辗蒲轮。 家传衣钵归龙凤，自指冰壶嗣颖滨。 赋诗二首呈懒翁 惊秋镜裹鬓边星，到处溪山皆洞庭。 怒雨打莲欹沼绿，颠风掣竹过墙青。 趁船紫燕辞芹渚，缩颈白鸥眠寥汀。 荷笠欲寻懒翕去，带些爽气入疏棂。 懒翁老白结忘年，秋入淡烟疏雨天。 醉把黑甜圆个梦，时将草圣放些颠。 杖藜还尽溪山债，杯酌结交风月绿。 梭督青童驰讷堑，鳞烦柴吏绩雄篇。 金华都似一揲大，却贮两枚诗酒仙。 六言六首呈懒翁 倦子冷居姑射，居士高卧毗耶。 钝置诗盟酒约，只自焚香吃荼。 酒恶频将花嗅，睡酣便把茶浇。 秋到梧桐枝上，夜来风雨潇潇。 金体青如竹叶，玉娥白似莲花。 闻君微恙脱体，杖藜欲访君家。 莲药嫌风狼藉，稻苗得雨精神。 翻忆武夷九曲，去秋蚁棹溪滨。 醉时枕上化蝶，睡起笔下生蛇。 日长心下无事，饥来只是餐霞。 秋雨识愁成段，暮云过眼生花。 栖凤亭中寂寞，武夷旧有仙家。 暮抵懒翁斋醉昤 旋开白酒买莲房，满泻桐膏照玉缸。 月女玲窥青斗帐，风神轻撼碧纱窗。 公疑我是今皇甫，我恐公为昔老庞。 醉后唾珠粘纸面，笑将笔力与人扛。 白莲诗 渊明归西天，不作东林社。 不见张昌宗，无人举此话。 谁家栽绿荷，熏风漾碧波，波底水晶空，化出玉垣娥。 嫣然玲无语，冰肌外晓雨。 东君如夏日，此花不受暑。 一点天然香，随风入画堂。 折之置坐隅，窈窕弄玉郎。 忽然心绪变，如睹佳人面。 寄语明月楼，莫贮双飞燕。 炼丹不成 八两日月精，半斤云雾屑。 轻似一鸿毛，重如千枰铁。 白如天上雪，红如猩猩血。 收入玉葫芦，秘之不敢泄。 夜半忽风雷，烟气满寥泬。 这般情与味，哑子咬破舌。 捧腹付一笑，无使心脑热。 要整钓鱼竿，再斫秋筠节。 修真十书武夷集卷之四十八竟 修真十书武夷集卷之四十九
chunks.translated_text:
A single flourish of the cinnabar talisman sends gods and ghosts fleeing,
Thunder and lightning shake heaven and earth.
Truly, such marvelous efficacy was unknown in ancient times—
Yet still, it has not been gathered to the celestial thoroughfare.

The moon is cold, the wind clear, a white crane cries,
A jeweled censer scatters rosy mist toward the distant Jade Flask.
The Master of Mount Wuyi delights in poetry and wine—
Once I saw you, but now you are gone.

**Inscribed on the Hall of Pure Emptiness**
The moon shifts, casting flower shadows beyond the window,
The wind carries the sound of pines to the pillow’s edge.
After dancing the long sword, I brew tea and taste it,
With a new poem composed, I embrace the zither and sleep.

Fresh wine is poured like green snail marrow,
Incense coils burn like purple horsewhips.
At the head of Nine-Bend Stream stands the Temple of Divine Protection—
Within the Hall of Pure Emptiness dwells a transcendent.

**First Encounter with the Lazy Old Man’s Poetry**
A handful of spirit soars far beyond the dust,
The Lazy One is no ordinary man.
Tao Yuanming’s pines and chrysanthemums remain evergreen,
Xie Lingyun’s pond and grasses are in spring’s prime.

He has already planted *gouqi* in the fields of magic mushrooms,
No need to grind the mossy steps with a chariot’s wheels.
The family’s robe and bowl are passed to dragons and phoenixes,
He himself points to the ice-pure flask, heir to Yingbin.

**Two Poems Presented to the Lazy Old Man**
Autumn’s mirror reveals stars at my temples,
Everywhere, streams and mountains are Dongting’s expanse.
Fierce rain strikes the lotus, tilting the green pond,
A gale snaps the bamboo, flinging it over the wall.

Purple swallows take flight from the water-chestnut isle,
White gulls tuck their necks to sleep on the desolate shoal.
I don a bamboo hat to seek the Lazy One,
Bringing a breath of crisp air through the lattice.

The Lazy Old Man and Old Bai form a bond across years,
Autumn enters the misty, sparse-rain sky.
Drunk, he dreams a perfect black-sweet dream,
At times, he lets the grass-script run wild.

Leaning on his staff, he repays the debts of streams and mountains,
With cups of wine, he befriends the wind and moon.
The Green Lad gallops across the moat,
The Wooden Clerk weaves heroic verses.

Jinhua is but a handful in size,
Yet it holds two immortals of poetry and wine.

**Six Six-Character Poems Presented to the Lazy Old Man**
The weary one coldly dwells on Guye,
The layman loftily sleeps in Vimalakirti’s realm.
Dull in poetry’s covenant and wine’s pact,
He merely burns incense and sips tea.

When the wine turns foul, he sniffs the flowers,
When sleep is deep, he pours tea to wake.
Autumn arrives on the wutong branches,
Night brings the sound of wind and rain.

His golden body is green as bamboo leaves,
The Jade Maiden white as lotus blossoms.
Hearing you are slightly unwell, body freed,
I lean on my staff, wishing to visit your home.

Lotus and herbs resent the wind’s havoc,
Rice seedlings gain spirit from the rain.
Recalling Mount Wuyi’s Nine Bends,
Last autumn, I poled a boat along the stream’s edge.

Drunk, I transformed into a butterfly on my pillow,
Awake, my brush gave birth to serpents.
Long days, my heart is free of cares,
When hungry, I merely dine on rosy clouds.

Autumn rain recognizes sorrow in segments,
Evening clouds pass before the eyes like blossoms.
The Phoenix Perch Pavilion stands desolate,
Yet Mount Wuyi once had immortals.

**Arriving Drunk at the Lazy Old Man’s Study and Singing**
Freshly opened white wine, lotus pods bought,
Poured full, tung oil shines in the jade vat.
The Moon Maiden peeks through the green canopy,
The Wind Spirit gently stirs the emerald gauze window.

You suspect I am today’s Huangfu,
I fear you are the old Pang of yore.
After drinking, I spit pearls that stick to the paper,
Laughing, I pit my brush’s strength against others.

**White Lotus Poem**
Yuanming returned to the Western Heaven,
No longer part of the Eastern Grove’s community.
No sign of Zhang Changzong,
No one speaks of this.

Whose home planted the green lotus,
Scented winds ripple the jade waves?
Beneath the waves, crystal emptiness,
From which emerges the Jade Mansion’s maiden.

Graceful, silent, and delicate,
Her ice-like skin bears the morning’s rain.
The Eastern Lord is like summer’s sun,
Yet this flower feels no heat.

A single point of natural fragrance,
Following the wind into the painted hall.
Plucked and placed in the corner of the seat,
She entices the jade-like gentleman.

Suddenly, my mood shifts,
As if gazing upon a beauty’s face.
I send word to the Pavilion of Bright Moonlight,
Do not house the pair of flying swallows.

**Failed Elixir**
Eight ounces of sun and moon’s essence,
Half a catty of cloud and mist’s fragments.
Light as a swan’s feather,
Heavy as a thousand scales of iron.

White as snow in the sky,
Red as a gibbon’s blood.
Gathered into a jade gourd,
Sealed, not daring to leak.

At midnight, sudden wind and thunder,
Smoke fills the vast emptiness.
Such flavor and feeling—
A mute bites his tongue in silence.

Clutching my belly, I laugh,
Lest my heart and brain grow fevered.
Better to mend my fishing rod,
And cut another section of autumn bamboo.

*The Forty-Eighth Scroll of Cultivating the True: Wuyi Collection Concludes*

chunks.original_text: 海南白玉蟾着 赠王太尉 笑曳华倨出禁廷，一声长啸万山青。 归来车马如云拥，扫去簪星似梦醒。 红码瑙杯斟白酒，碧珊瑚枕倚朱屏。 也须趁取些强学，作个唐人五达灵。 复卢艮庵韵 拟占朝班最上头，官清冷似一天秋。 风花雪月千金子，水竹云山万户侯。 海客盟鸥终不动，塞翁失马更何求。 明窗诤几华胥外，蝴蝶翩翩自梦周。 题张知丞修然轩 不着人间一点尘，翛然一室贮幽人。 清宵瓮下酒中圣，白昼笔头诗泣神。 芳草惜锄怜绿浄，落花慵扫爱红匀。 棋声隔断华胥路，自把博山烧暮春。 和叶宰韵题震无咎斋 蜗角蝇头既可憎，如何又问利和名。 学他太古先天妙，合取中庸一点诚。 乾坤所谓日月祖，坎离乃是天地精。 工夫学到震无咎，只字拔茅乘泰亨。 立秋有怀陈上舍 没巴没鼻落一叶，发颠发狂何处风。 九十日暑扫地去，满怀汗珠寻已空。 却烦察判潘孺子，说与上舍陈友龙。 来宵无雨必好月，一樽还要与君同。 梦中得五十六字 醉醒曳杖访松关，正在黄昏杳霭间。 既去复来秋后暑，似无还有雨中山。 涧边几叶晚花落，天际一钩明月弯。 自觉余烟埋屐齿，行行印破藓痕斑。 胡中隐庵中伤春 尽把天工付祝融，东皇归去太华宫。 棱棱山色耸苍玉，湛湛波光浸碧铜。 杨柳入天鸠要雨，海棠落地蝶嫌风。 好将杖屦西园看，万紫千红一夜空。 寓息庵送春 笔下自然诗料饱，天工仃出好山溪。 鱼知水暖不胜跃，莺见花飞只管啼。 树头鸠使妇唤雨，屋后竹教孙出泥。 太白十杯人酩醉，碧桃洞口日衔西。 胡子赢庵中偶题 道人惯吃胡麻饭，来到人问今几年。 白玉楼前空夜月，紫金殿上起春烟。 闲倾一盏中黄酒，闷扫千章内景篇。 昨夜锺离传好语，教吾且作地行仙。 赠天台老樊 别后俄惊几许春，相逢一笑抱南熏。 灰头土面无人识，不食草衣嫌俗纷。 在浙之台今已久，姓樊名邴寂无闻。 为君传此新诗去，寄与铅山赵翠云。 赠吴草裘 闻道青城有老昊，话头入耳十年余。 偶同姿女无忧客，来到天台撞见渠。 身上衣衫惟素布，口中谈吐尽丹书。 想君已是千余岁，谁道神仙世上无。 寄苏侍郎 往古来今如换肩，我疑公便是坡仙。 满城都没个伯乐，一日可能无乐天。 方且论文俄判袂，不知握手又何年。 忽然铁笛一声响，响到金华古洞边。 天开书楼图 层檐迭嗽入苍冥，千山万山相送迎。 晴云已抹收未了，溪尾更濯余霞明。 化工朝暮费点染，丹青变态堕深浅。 凭栏展空千里眼，却愁此轴难舒卷。 赠危法师 曾见先生在九华，朝餐玉乳着琼花。 鹿冠夜戴青城月，鹤氅晨披紫府霞。 偶携剑在人间世，未把琴归仙子家。 一笑相逢松竹裹，炷香新话啜杯茶。 游杨梓岩 天半秋风呜万松，羌花半落夕阳红。 寮烟暗锁仙坛古，野草深藏丹鳌空。 人采紫芝何处觅，我来白昼不相逢。 一声箫管笑扬袂，秋色满怀诗兴浓。 燕岩游罢与岩主话别 西风吹作此岩游，满目松筠翠欲流。 玉燕不飞明月夜，石锺一振晓霜秋。 惜乎分手便南北，忽尔回头欲去留。 且去人间办丹料，却来山顶结茅休。 题舒氏难老亭 别是人间一洞天，桩松郁郁起祥烟。 德同桂种不知岁，福与水流无尽年。 萱草堂前千古事，莲花池上两神仙。 莱衣戏彩人无恙，结尽溪山风月绿。 三十三天第一天，玉皇殿下袅轻烟。

**By Bai Yuchan of Hainan**

**To Grand Preceptor Wang**
Laughing, you stride from the palace gates,
A single long whistle turns ten thousand peaks green.
Returning, carriages and horses crowd like clouds,
Sweeping away court stars—awake from a dream.

Ruby agate cups brim with white wine,
A coral pillow leans against a vermilion screen.
Yet you must seize this strength to study,
To become one of the Tang’s five transcendent sages.

**Matching Lu Gen’an’s Rhyme**
I once stood at the head of the morning court,
My office as cold and clear as autumn skies.
Wind, flowers, snow, moon—worth a thousand gold coins,
Water, bamboo, clouds, mountains—worth ten thousand households.

The sea traveler’s pact with gulls remains unbroken,
The frontier elder’s lost horse seeks no more.
Beyond the bright window and upright desk,
Butterflies flutter through the dream of *Huaxu*.

**Inscribed on Zhang Zhineng’s *Xiu Ran* Pavilion**
Untouched by the world’s slightest dust,
A solitary man dwells in quiet seclusion.
On clear nights, a saint beneath the wine jar,
By day, poems from his brush move the gods to tears.

Tender grass grieves the hoe’s green purity,
Fallen blossoms, unraked, love their crimson evenness.
Chess sounds sever the path to *Huaxu*,
As he burns incense in the *Boshan* censer at dusk.

**Matching Ye Zai’s Rhyme on *Zhen Wujiu* Studio**
Snail-horn, fly-head gains—how detestable!
Why ask again of profit and fame?
Learn the wondrous precelestial Dao of high antiquity,
And embrace the single sincerity of the *Doctrine of the Mean*.

Heaven and earth are the sun and moon’s ancestors,
*Kan* and *Li* are the essence of sky and earth.
When study reaches *Zhen Wujiu*,
A single word uproots the thatch, riding the great *Tai* prosperity.

**On the Autumn Equinox, Thinking of Clerk Chen**
A noseless, earless leaf falls—
Where is the wind that maddens and topples?
Ninety days of heat swept clean away,
The sweat in my breast already vanished.

I trouble the astute Judge Pan,
To tell Clerk Chen, our Friend Long:
If tonight brings no rain, the moon will be fine—
One cup of wine must still be shared with you.

**Fifty-Six Characters Composed in a Dream**
Drunk and sober, I lean on my staff to visit Pine Pass,
Just at dusk, amid deepening mist.
Departed, yet returning—autumn’s lingering heat,
Seemingly absent, yet present—mountains in the rain.

By the stream, a few late blossoms fall,
At the sky’s edge, a crescent moon bends.
I sense the lingering smoke burying my sandal teeth,
Step by step, imprinting the moss’s mottled traces.

**In Hu’s Hidden Hut, Lamenting Spring**
I leave all creation to *Zhurong*,
As the Eastern Emperor returns to *Taihua Palace*.
Mountains stand sharp as green jade,
Waves shimmer, soaking bronze’s sheen.

Willows reach the sky—doves summon rain,
Crabapples fall to earth—butterflies shun the wind.
Best to take staff and sandals to the western garden,
Where ten thousand purples and reds vanish in a single night.

**Sending Spring Off from the Lodge of Rest**
Poems flow naturally from the brush, rich with material,
Heaven’s craft carves fine mountain streams.
Fish, knowing the water’s warmth, leap without cease,
Orioles, seeing flowers fly, cry endlessly.

The tree-top turtledove’s wife calls for rain,
Bamboo behind the hut teaches its shoots to rise from mud.
After ten cups of *Taibai*, one is dead drunk—
At the mouth of the Peach Blossom Grotto, the sun sinks west.

**Occasional Lines in Hu’s Winning Hut**
The Daoist is used to eating sesame rice,
Arriving in the world—how many years has it been?
Before the White Jade Tower, the moon of night is empty,
Above the Purple Gold Hall, spring mist rises.

Leisurely, he pours a cup of *Zhonghuang* wine,
Bored, he sweeps a thousand chapters of *Neijing* scriptures.
Last night, *Zhongli* passed down kind words,
Teaching me to become an earth-walking immortal for now.

**To Old Fan of Tiantai**
Since parting, how many springs have startled us?
Meeting again, we laugh, embracing the southern breeze.
Ashen-faced, dust-covered—no one recognizes us,
Refusing to eat grass-cloth, disdaining worldly fuss.

In Zhe’s Tiantai, you’ve long resided,
Your name, Fan Bing, unknown and obscure.
I send these new poems to you,
To deliver to Zhao Cuiyun of Qianshan.

**To Wu Caoqiu**
I hear that on Green City Mountain lives Old Hao,
His words, entering my ears, now ten years past.
By chance, with the carefree traveler and the joyless maiden,
I came to Tiantai and met him.

His clothes are plain hemp,
His speech all alchemical texts.
I think you are already over a thousand years old—
Who says immortals do not exist in this world?

**To Vice Minister Su**
Past and present shift like shoulders,
I suspect you are Su Shi reborn.
The whole city lacks a single *Bo Le*—
Could there be a day without a *Le Tian*?

Just now discussing literature, we part abruptly,
Unknowing when we’ll clasp hands again.
Suddenly, an iron flute sounds—
Its notes reach the ancient grottoes of Jinhua.

**Painting of the Heaven-Opened Library Tower**
Layered eaves rise into the azure void,
A thousand peaks, ten thousand peaks, sending and welcoming.
Clear clouds, already wiped away, linger unfinished,
At the stream’s end, the last glow of sunset gleams.

Nature’s craft, morning and night, applies its touches,
Ink and colors shift in depth and hue.
Leaning on the railing, I stretch my thousand-mile gaze,
Yet grieve that this scroll cannot be fully unfurled.

**To Master Wei**
I once saw you on Jiuhua Mountain,
Morning feasting on jade milk and jasper flowers.
At night, a deer-horn cap beneath the moon of Green City,
At dawn, a crane cloak draped in purple palace mist.

Occasionally, you carry a sword in the human world,
Yet have not taken your zither to the immortals’ home.
Laughing, we meet amid pines and bamboo,
Burning incense, sipping tea, sharing new words.

**Visiting Yangzi Cliff**
Halfway up the sky, autumn wind sighs through ten thousand pines,
Qiang flowers half-fallen in the reddening sunset.
Hermitage smoke veils the ancient immortal altar,
Wild grass hides the empty cinnabar cauldron.

Where do people gather purple mushrooms?
I come at noon, yet find no one.
A single note of flute and pipe—laughing, I raise my sleeves,
Autumn’s hues fill my breast, my poetic mood thickens.

**After Visiting Yan Cliff, Parting with Its Master**
The west wind blows me to this cliff’s wanderings,
My eyes brim with emerald pines and bamboos.
Jade swallows do not fly on moonlit nights,
A stone bell’s chime startles the frosty autumn dawn.

Alas, we part—north and south diverging,
Suddenly turning back, torn between leaving and staying.
Go first to the human world to prepare elixir ingredients,
Then return to the mountain’s peak to build a thatched hut and rest.

**Inscribed on the Shu Family’s *Nan Lao* Pavilion**
A separate cave-heaven in the human world,
Stalwart pines rise in dense, auspicious mist.
Virtue like cassia seeds, unaware of the years,
Fortune like flowing water, endless in time.

Before the *Xuan* grass hall, affairs of a thousand ages,
Atop the lotus pond, two immortals.
The man in *lai* robes, playing with colors, remains unharmed—
He weaves all the streams and mountains into green wind and moon.

The thirty-third heaven’s first day,
Beneath the Jade Emperor’s palace, wispy smoke curls.

chunks.translated_text:
Unknowing of kalpas, what era is this now?
Just the second year of Yan Kang’s reign.
Weak waters admit no boat—homeward bound like an arrow,
While Hua Xu’s dreams invite a roaming immortal’s play.

Seated before the *Nan Lao* Pavilion, staff in hand,
I kindle incense and steep tea in emerald depths.

**To the Lute Guest Lu Yuan-zhang**
A shard of frigid crystal in hand,
Ten fingers strike and pluck like jade’s chime.
The tune plays *White Snow* and *Yang Chun*’s mode,
Its melody the sound of lofty mountains and flowing streams.
Pine tops echo crane cries at midnight’s half,
Cold mist hangs still, the wind’s chill whisper.
Paper quilt and tile pillow cold as water,
Tossing sleepless, no dream comes.
Rising to scratch my head, I strum one piece,
Chanting done, the autumn moon illumines the mountain.

**Inscribed on the Hermit’s Lodge**
Fine pines, fine bamboos, fine streams and hills,
Carriages and horses throng, coming and going.
Travelers hear the new wine’s white froth,
Entering, they tread through tender moss’s speckled green.
I say this pure seclusion beyond the world
Is yet like a bustling marketplace’s clamor.
Valleys’ grain and mulberries fill empty huts,
The host attends guests, never idle.

**Rainy Inscription at a Traveler’s Inn**
Wind stirs the vast sky, autumn rain hangs,
The road slick as moss, I lazily shake the whip.
Entering, I bid the servant buy a cup of wine,
Grind ink, lean by the window, chant a verse.
Yellow bamboo beneath the far eaves, yellow ants war,
White reeds mirror the water where white gulls sleep.
A long whistle, then I depart,
Turning back, the lone village fades in evening mist.

**Golden Immortal Pavilion at Immortal Crag**
Cold mist seals the Brahma-king’s abode,
A single censer’s smoke coils like a coiling snake.
Autumn rain falls like jade flowers across the sky,
The clear stream swells green, submerging level sands.
Ancient pines and jagged rocks vie in height,
Green vines drag trees, veiling clouds.
Bamboo roots upturn, crow wings aslant,
Midnight’s cold wind stirs roosting crows.
The wooden fish calls for congee, butterflies wake,
At the cliff’s edge, the waning moon sinks into the cinnabar well.

**The Indolent Hut**
Once a name in the Scarlet Towers’ pure capital,
This life drifts, carefree, following nature’s truth.
Across the window, an ancient inkstone holds water of bygone ages,
On the wall, a neglected lute gathers days of dust.
Leave the creeping grasses unweeded, still by the stones,
Let fallen blossoms lie unbrushed, even with the moss.
Enlist the wind as a gate-keeping servant,
Borrow the moon as a wine-companion.
Histories and classics hold silent, ancient savor,
Barriers and mountains stand unmoved, a painting’s spirit.
With tea at hand, I’ll not wage snail wars,
Without dreams, I’ll not take a butterfly’s form.
What idle matters occupy me?
Beyond the eaves, birds know the same spring.

**The Joyful Studio**
A recluse’s retreat amid pines and bamboos,
A small hall reclines beneath the northern mountain’s shade.
Deep night, the cold moon chills the thatched door,
Dawn’s rise, the clear wind refreshes the paper quilt.
Grasping the sword, I drink wine from the cup’s face,
Stowing books, I disturb the wall-hung lute.
Since glimpsing Fuxi’s visage,
Who through the ages has known the nurturing of a vast heart?

**Heavenly Valley Hermitage**
Halfway to heaven, a singular peak juts,
A tiny thatched hut holds rich savor.
Flanking the path, new pines beckon the night moon,
The grove’s dense bamboos summon autumn winds.
Wild birds greet with intricate calls,
Rock flowers vex with their riotous red.
Leaning on my staff, I follow the flowing stream,
The brushwood gate often sealed by white clouds.

**The Chamber of Descending Perfection**
Jade chimes resound, colored incense swirls,
Beyond the window, azure birds cry at midnight’s half.
Pines and bamboos, silent, vie for earth’s stillness,
Stars seem pluckable, the sky feels low.
Golden chariots rise at the yellow-clouded eave’s corner,
A jade ladder unfurls from the moonlit roof’s edge.
Bowing to the Purple Emperor after the first feast,
The *bu xu* chant fades, begging for the elixir’s measure.

**To the Indolent Hut’s Lu, Vice Officer**
Mountain hues congeal in layered emerald clouds,
Crow cries startle the setting sun to red.
I’d carry the lute to play beneath autumn’s moon,
Or snatch the chessboard to move with the evening breeze.
Once drunk and asleep, I know affairs grow few,
Several chants clear, the heart feels empty.
The Indolent Hut keeps no company,
Its barred brushwood gate holds rich savor.

**Lu Shu-yu’s Pavilion of Pure Poverty**
Utterly carefree, heedless of heaven,
At five *zhang*’s height, the sun lingers, yet he sleeps on.
Stream fish and village wine hold uncommon savor,
Wild greens and mountain grains cost no coin.
An urn for a window, a painted gate blocks the narrow path,
Dry firewood and white rice boil in clear spring water.
Sometimes leaning on a staff by the verdant pines,
He is the human world’s blissful immortal.

**The Inferior Recluse**
Worldly warmth and chill sting the nose,
The cave’s gate stands ajar, green mist chills.
Grasping a three-foot sword, I dance in the wind,
Holding a lute, I play to the moon.
I hew bamboo to let water pass,
Lean on pines half the day, clasping scriptures.
In the heart’s leisure amid mountains and forests,
I refine the elixir of deathless life.

**The Forty-Ninth Scroll of *Ten Books on Cultivating Perfection: Wuyi Collection* Concludes**

chunks.original_text: 海南白玉蟾着 思微堂 访灵宝观，咏思微堂灵宝中盟镰，有思微定志券，因以命名，取为之昤曰： 思微堂裹自冲虚，高士闲居兴味殊。 月冷花开数朵静，风清乌过一声孤。 谁知心上工夫妙，欲觅人间俗累无。 九转内丹成也未，快骑白鹤去天衢。 题上清法堂壁 秋雨悬天风作寒，冷烟锁住屋头山。 半岩飞乌一声过，峭壁断云千古闲。 世俗不知幽静处，神仙隐在有无间。 夜来小艇篙脱手，醉把霜竿入翠湾。 太虚堂 满堂冷静爽精神，不着人间一点尘。 檐鹊噪风呼薄晚，庭花飘露落残春。 华胥上国今无梦，龙汉元年古有身。 香篆飞从窗外去，云梢孤鹤唳何人。 三华院还丹诗 绛宫无事绝尘埃，坎虎离龙战几回。 白雪飞空铅药绽，黄云覆鼎汞花开。 龟蛇抱一成丹药，乌兔凝真结圣胎。 夜半瀛洲寒月落，冷风吹鹤上蓬莱。 送江子恭三首 我欲杨村结草庐，不知踪迹又江湖。 回观咫尺如天远，自别丰标仅月余。 忽一二时思故旧，整千百里望音书。 忆君不忍忘怀处，一片青云点太虚。 春来行尽烂田畦，云满春空水满溪。 风漾碧波翻麦珑，日晴红雨落桃蹊。 杜鹃声断惊寒兔，蝴蝶梦残听晓鸡。 人在江束寄归信，海棠花谢燕衔泥。 子到铅山我信州，笋舆轧轧又归休。 数程细雨斜风路，一片落花啼乌愁。 何必便为阮籍哭，不来相伴赤松游。 他年我到蓬莱去，一粒金丹汝去不？ 送张大师 自从汝离武夷来，险阻艰难历几回。 江左旅中连值雨，春深路上滑成苔。 乌啼花片落流水，风惨猿声啸古台。 举眼四山如壁立，教君归去也心灰。 赠杜省元 海外三山一洞天，金楼玉室有神仙。 南柯国裹柯岩叟，白马江边马自然。 鲸脯味甘供老广，黄麻饭熟饲彭钱。 金丹炼就炉无火，桃再开花经几年。 淡庵倪清父 地僻人闲春昼长，了然物我两相忘。 薄披明月归诗肆，细切清风入醉乡。 蜡味溪山闲裹嚼，薹羹松竹静中尝。 把琴弹破世间事，浄几明窗一灶香。 倪敬父柯山 暮云横翠夕阳斜，啼罢歌楼林外鸦。 绿竹弄摇风裹影，碧桃开遍雨中花。 三杯淡酒邀明月，一局残棋惊落霞。 人在柯山山上咏，笑挥管笔走生蛇。 酬蒋知观所惠诗 新雁飞来一朵云，读之毛骨耸寒鳞。 展开大句几钩墨，存想先生满面春。 榻上宾朋谈盛德，山中冠褐混凡身。 来朝盥手灶香去，恐是蓬莱相识人。 赞钟 闻道琳宫欲范锺，上皇勃赐万斤铜。 一模脱出等闲事，千古要知陶铸功。 敲得星飞惊落月，撞教云破响呼风。 子今欲为吾皇寿，笑指琼楼贴碧空。 靖通庵 靖通庵外锁晴云，壁莹飞琼瓦迭鳞。 野乌无心一声晓，岩花有意四时春。 凿开风月长生地，占断烟霞不老身。 虚靖当年仙去后，不知丹诀付何人。 澹庵 平生只要乐清虚，占断人间静处居。 古壁空悬三尺剑，幽窗闲却一床书。 远山喜色日初染，枯木凉声风自梳。 细嚼清闲滋味别，云霞收拾作粮储。 假山 一林幽竹几时栽，怪石花砖砌绿苔。 羽客游岩乘雨至，仙翁采药破云来。 天台犹在眉毛耸，马荡依然眼睫开。 昨夜摘珠人报道，海边失却小蓬莱。 美周都监祷雨验 旱魑为妖欲请雩，真人问雨几时无。 先将凤表投金阙，拟向龙潭下铁符。 弹指雷呜三霹雳，举头云起一须臾。 笑将斗柄轻轻序，倒泻银河万斛珠。 别句呈庚契吴高士

**Written by Hai'nan Bai Yuchan at Simwei Hall, Visiting Lingbao Abbey**

At Simwei Hall within Lingbao’s sacred precinct,
A pact of subtle alliance, a covenant of steadfast intent—
Thus named, I chant:

Within Simwei Hall, emptiness reigns,
A lofty scholar’s retreat, where tastes diverge.
Moon cold, a few blossoms bloom in stillness,
Wind clear, a lone crow’s cry traverses the void.
Who knows the marvel of the heart’s work?
Seeking a world untouched by worldly burdens.
Has the ninefold inner elixir formed yet?
Swiftly ride the white crane to Heaven’s thoroughfare.

**Inscribed on the Wall of the Upper Clarity Method Hall**

Autumn rain hangs from the sky, wind sharpens the cold,
Chill mist seals the mountain above the eaves.
A bird darts past the half-cliff’s edge,
Sheer crags sever clouds—timeless leisure.
The vulgar know not this secluded quiet,
Where immortals hide between being and non-being.
Last night, the skiff’s pole slipped from my grasp,
Drunk, I cast the frosted rod into the emerald bay.

**Hall of Great Emptiness**

The hall stands cool and still, refreshing the spirit,
Unstained by a speck of the human world’s dust.
Eaves magpies clamor in the wind, calling dusk,
Courtyard blossoms scatter dew, lingering spring’s end.
The land of Hua Xu holds no dreams now,
Yet in the Dragon Han’s first kalpa, this body once was.
Incense smoke drifts beyond the window,
A lone crane’s cry—who calls from the cloud’s edge?

**Returning Elixir Poems of the Three Flowers Abbey**

The Crimson Palace lies at ease, free of dust,
Kan’s tiger and Li’s dragon wage countless battles.
White snow flies through the void as lead blooms,
Yellow clouds shroud the crucible as mercury flowers unfold.
Tortoise and serpent embrace unity, forming the elixir,
Raven and hare congeal truth, shaping the sacred embryo.
At midnight, beneath Yingzhou’s cold moon,
A chill wind carries the crane to Penglai.

**Three Poems Sending Off Jiang Zigong**

I wished to build a thatched hut by Yang Village,
Yet my traces drift once more to rivers and lakes.
Looking back, a footstep seems as distant as the sky,
Since parting, barely a month has passed.
In fleeting moments, I think of old friends,
Across a thousand miles, I long for word.
The memory of you lingers, unbearable to forget—
A wisp of blue cloud dots the great void.

Spring arrives, traversing lush fields,
Clouds fill the spring sky, water brims the streams.
Wind ripples green waves, barley sways,
Sun shines, red rain falls on peach-lined paths.
The cuckoo’s cry fades, startling the cold hare,
The butterfly’s dream ends, roused by the dawn cock.
You dwell east of the river, sending word home—
As crabapple blossoms fade, swallows carry mud.

You reach Lead Mountain, I remain in Xin Prefecture,
The bamboo sedan creaks, then rests once more.
Through misty rain and slanting winds, the road winds,
A scattering of fallen blossoms grieves the cawing crow.
Why weep like Ruan Ji?
Come, wander with Red Pine instead.
One day, when I ascend Penglai,
Will you follow, bearing a grain of golden elixir?

**Sending Off Master Zhang**

Since you left Mount Wu,
How many perils and hardships have you endured?
On the Jiang’s left bank, rain has dogged your travels,
Spring’s deep roads slick with moss.
Crows cry, petals drift on flowing water,
Wind howls, gibbons shriek from ancient terraces.
Lifting your gaze, four mountains stand like walls—
Even you, returning, may find your heart ashen.

**Presented to Du Xingyuan**

Beyond the seas, three mountains form a grotto-heaven,
Golden towers and jade chambers house immortals.
In Nanke’s land dwells the Cassia Rock Elder,
By White Horse River, Horse Ziran.
Whale flesh, sweet, feeds the aged Guang,
Yellow hemp rice, ripe, nourishes Peng Qian.
The golden elixir refined, the furnace holds no fire—
How many years since the peach bloomed again?

**Niqingfu of Dan’an**

Secluded land, idle folk, spring days stretch long,
All is forgotten—self and world alike.
A thin moon’s light draped over returning to the poetry shop,
A gentle breeze sliced into the realm of drunkenness.
Wax-flavored streams and mountains, leisurely chewed,
Water-shield broth with pine and bamboo, savored in stillness.
Plucking the lute, I shatter worldly affairs,
A pure desk, bright window, a single burner’s incense.

**Nijingfu of Keshan**

Dusk clouds stretch across green slopes, the sun slants,
The song tower’s echoes fade, crows call beyond the woods.
Green bamboo sways, shadows dancing in the wind,
Peach blossoms bloom in profusion amid the rain.
Three cups of pale wine invite the bright moon,
A half-finished game of chess startles the falling glow.
On Keshan’s heights, he chants,
Laughing, wields his brush, ink strokes writhing like serpents.

**In Response to Poems Presented by Jiang Zhiguan**

New geese arrive, trailing a wisp of cloud,
Reading them, my hair stands on end, my scales bristle.
Unfurling grand lines, a few strokes of ink,
I envision the master’s face, all smiles.
On the couch, guests and friends speak of noble virtue,
In the mountains, the capped and gowned mingle with the mundane.
Tomorrow, I’ll wash my hands, tend the incense burner,
Fearing you may be an acquaintance from Penglai.

**In Praise of the Bell**

I hear the numinous palace is to cast a bell,
The August Emperor bestows ten thousand catties of bronze.
A single mold’s release—no trifling matter,
For a thousand ages, know the alchemy’s craft.
Struck, stars scatter, the moon falls,
Rung, clouds part, the wind howls.
Now, to extend our sovereign’s years,
I point and laugh at the jade towers clinging to the azure sky.

**Jingtong Abbey**

Beyond Jingtong Abbey, clear clouds are locked,
Walls gleam like flying jasper, tiles layered like scales.
Wild birds, unconcerned, cry at dawn,
Cliff blossoms, intentional, bloom through the four seasons.
Carved from wind and moon, a land of immortality,
Seizing mist and rosy clouds, a body that never ages.
Since Master Xu Jing departed as an immortal,
I wonder to whom he entrusted the elixir’s secret.

**Dan’an**

All my life, I sought only joy in purity and emptiness,
Claiming the quietest dwelling in the human world.
An ancient wall bears a three-foot sword,
A secluded window holds a bed of books.
Distant mountains brighten as the sun rises,
Withered trees chill as the wind combs them.
Savoring the subtle flavor of leisure,
I gather clouds and mist for sustenance.

**The Rockery**

When were these groves of bamboo planted?
Strange stones and patterned bricks cradle green moss.
Feathered guests wander the crags, arriving with the rain,
Immortal elders pluck herbs, parting the clouds.
Mount Tiantai still arches like brows,
Ma Dang remains open like eyes.
Last night, pearl-gatherers reported
The isle of Penglai lost beyond the sea.

**Prayer for Rain Answered by Marshal Zhou**

Drought demons scheme, demanding the *yu* rite,
When will the true man bring rain?
First, present the phoenix memorial to the golden palace,
Then cast the iron talisman into the dragon pool.
With a flick of the finger, thunder roars in three peals,
Lifting my gaze, clouds rise in an instant.
Laughing, I adjust the Dipper’s handle,
Tipping the Silver River to spill ten thousand bushels of pearls.

**Parting Lines for Master Geng and Hermit Wu**

A Chance Meeting on Verdant Heights

A shared laugh as we meet in emerald mist,
Green locusts and towering willows lend their cool.
My heart stirs with waters, bamboos, mist, and clouds—
Let winds, blossoms, snow, and moon be the ones who know.

The sun sets; three cups of idle wine,
Idle hours yield eight lines of effortless verse.
Tomorrow, clouds will drift beyond the blue peaks—
Shall we turn to hear only gibbons and cranes sigh?

Meng Valley

Pale mist lightly binds a few pines,
Night deepens, the ancient valley wind sighs.
Clouds veil the grass, unfolding green in the ravine,
Birds carry fallen blossoms, crimson on the jade cliffs.

Since immortals departed, no golden sword remains,
Since officials arrived, jade paulownias stand.
Who will now retreat to these secluded peaks?
Southward, a few lone summits brood in silence.

Plum Window

A southern window frames a few eaves,
A touch of warmth stirs to life.
Branches bear snow’s lean grains,
Walls catch the wind’s pure chill.

Frost-laden wine warms itself,
Moonlit dreams refuse to form.
From where does the flute’s note come,
Sending its few strains at dusk?

Zhang Jinfu’s Quiet Lodge

Shedding the world, he sleeps amid clouds,
His breast holds another heaven.
Five or six couches line the walls,
Two or three rafters span the roof.

Wind and moon offer true savor,
Streams and mountains wear their old green.
In stillness lies true stillness—
Gibbons cry at dusk along the forest’s edge.

Reflections on the Start of Autumn

Years fly swift as arrows,
Sun and moon leap like pellets.
The Fire Emperor relinquishes his seal,
The White Emperor dons his cap once more.

Just as we rejoice in the end of heat,
We are made to dread the coming cold.
Life is but this—
Unbidden, the nose stings with sorrow.

Lei Yizhen’s "A Recluse’s Farewell to Spring"

Heaven would not keep spring,
The Eastern Lord steals away unseen.
On the emerald paulownia’s boughs,
A sighing wind bears rain.

Awakening from Traveler’s Slumber

Clouds pile jade upon the mountains,
Rain entreats the grass to deepen its green.
A single dream of Southern Branch—
Suddenly, a crow’s call rouses me.

On the Four Immortals

Han Xiang:
White snow fills the night sky,
A single golden sprout heralds spring.
After returning from Blue Pass,
What care for the world’s folk?

Chen Qi:
A scroll no one can read,
A thousand goblets shared with guests.
Peach blossoms bloom, nearly spent,
Yet still he lingers by the cold crags.

He Xiangu:
No trace in the celestial gardens,
Yet the Tang annals record her name.
Who knows the Red Jade Grotto?
A thousand years echo with night gibbons’ cries.

Cao Guojiu:
He stole the Jade Capital’s peach,
Trampled the capital’s grasses to dust.
White snow fills his straw cloak—
Within lies the treasure of the golden elixir.

Inscribed at Hu Yungan’s Villa

Boredom turns to bamboo; flowers are scorned,
Idly gazing at mountains, I raise the blind.
A fine bird’s cry wings past the eaves,
A pure breeze lends its strength to the silver toad.

A single brazier at Mount Bo, its small snakes chilled,
No one else sits alone on the rush mat.
The brushwood gate is entrusted to the wind’s latch—
Beyond the eaves, white clouds come and go.

On Han Xiang

Your uncle played the part of death to the hilt,
Emerging from the snow with no thought for the world.
Fortunate to have that basket of blossoms from years past—
Even now, it’s passed to some idle monk.

The Solitary Firefly

Night still, I sit frost-chilled by the water pavilion,
A lone firefly flickers among the grasses.
In a flash, it skims the silver pond’s surface—
Two stars of floating light, now high, now low.

*Cultivating the True: Wuyi Anthology, Scroll Fifty* concludes.
*Cultivating the True: Wuyi Anthology, Scroll Fifty-One* begins.

Laughing, I adjust the Dipper’s handle,
Tipping the Silver River to spill ten thousand bushels of pearls.

**Parting Lines for Master Geng and Hermit Wu**

chunks.original_text: 海南白玉蟾着 龙虎山祈雨早行有作 两三条电复无雨，六七点星微上云。 鞭起卧龙我骑去，挥戈叱问五雷君。 中秋月 风吹玉露洗银河，爽气平分桂影高。 把笛倚楼人不寐，此心直拟数秋毫。 钱塘江上雪飞花，人在天边泛海搓。 乌鹊一声星斗落，垣娥梳洗去谁家。 千崖爽气已平分，万里青天辗玉轮。 好向钱塘江上望，相逢都是广寒人。 卧云 满室天香仙子家，一琴一剑一杯荼。 羽衣常带烟霞色，不惹人间桃李花。 织机 试神童日，韩郡王令其赋之。 天地山河作织机，百花如锦柳如丝。 虚空白处做一疋，日月双梭天外飞。 舟行 山锁晓烟迷紫翠，花凝宿雨间青红。 快帆幸自泛新绿，乞与一篙东去风。 上清宫方丈后亭 三四声猿叫落月，六七竿竹呼起风。 夜静无人知此味，还他方丈拙庵翁。 赠吴道士 香篆之余，玉童荐觞，对谭诗味，心思风清，僭有一绝，斤斧可也。 延陵大士诗中虎，接武黄陈肩李杜。 无盥争敢陋西施，也向雷门声布鼓。 赠何道人 冠褐满天下，几个能贤贤。 忽来龙虎山，结这粥饭绿。 方丈最高处，幽居今几年。 一双岩电眼，识尽地行仙。 又 汞虎铅龙炼气神，黄芽昨夜一枝春。 刀圭底事如何会，伏虎朱砂匮水银。 赠张知堂 清河知堂武当来，左日右月双眼开。 高卧云堂留梦醒，笑骑白鹤归蓬莱。 赠云谷孔全道 凝神爽气炼金丹，七返从来有九还。 昨夜一声雷霹雳，不知人己在泥丸。 赠胡葆元 业儒为见儒多恨，学道绿吾道化贤。 且把功名权架阁，抱琴随我去修仙。 赠薛氏绳歌 其青节如竹之青，其白气如梅之白。 有时抱置假山边，被人唤作谪仙客。 赠薛氏振歌 麒角独异凤毛轻，得龙之秀龟之清。 麟凤龟龙谓四灵，尔曹骨气同峥嵘。 与赵寺丞 汞铅不在身中取，龙虎当於意外求。 会得这些真造化，何愁不晓炼丹头。 题潘察院竹园壁 夜雨洗开千翡翠，春风撼碎万琅玕。 满林鸦鹊卧明月，铁笛一声烟正寒。 赠徐翔卿之别 桃花落地雨漫漫，子乃担双过万山。 临别有些无尽意，篇诗送子到崇安。 题莫干山 封到半天烟霭间，一卷仙书一粒丹。 城北城南元老树，又吹竹笛过前山。 题胡子山林擒坡 洞宾踢碎金葫芦，夜半垣娥下药珠。 但见满天尽角角，不知春去鬼椰偷。 颐庵喜神赞 江月射双眼，岩云飞两眉。 自是上饶一团和气，点化自家方寸真机。 能落笔，作泣鬼神之诗； 能坐石，下烂柯之棋。 千人万人瞻礼不已，笑骑白鹿独步天墀。 隶轩真赞 骨气已神仙，玄圃挺生贤。 面上四时春，心次一壶天。 人皆就法门，楝梁上绰他光景； 我道隶轩高士，志趣飘然。 若也未知涯挨，为君指出言诠。 丹成若未归蓬岛，且结溪山风月绿。 潘龙游喜神赞 龙章凤姿，既非嵇叔夜； 弯颔虎颈，又非斑定远。 机呜籁动，听其自然。 虚心何物，何增何损。 花满一壶春色好，半斑顿露与人看。 郭信叔喜神赞 万丈崖头立一梯，百丈竿头垂一手。 绵团曩铁云包月，麒麟海裹翻筋斗。 回天拓地立教门，斩新气盘鼎乾坤。 倪王人指碧溪水，尽是渠侬元尽恩。 谁乎冲靖之上足，郭信叔者也。 薛直岁喜神赞 和风满面紫芝春，双脸常如酒半醺。 法录把除符券柄，宗门立尽栋梁勋。 凤冠夜戴琼林月，鹤氅朝披玉洞云。 自是神仙真气象，多生曾是薛真君。 吊刘心月

chunks.original_text: 刘妙清入水而逝，我来吊以一章。 汨罗江上水呜咀，鱼鳌不知老龙泣，徒棹龙舟何处寻，何不办取屈原生前一枝楫。 大昊江边伍侯庙，夕阳满树闻啼乌，行人过此焚纸钱，何不办取子胥生前一杯酒。 屈伍死后今寥寥，其名千古如一朝。 江边垂泪知几人，冰魂雪魄不可招。 哀哉道人刘心月，其身贫甚其性烈。 少年虽落风尘中，末后猛省自摆脱。 其心虽美其名腥，一旦死于武夷溪之滨，却将九曲溪中水，洗却千愁万恨身。 曹娥寻父尸赴水，死作妇女英灵鬼。 柳翠萧琼俱水亡，但见渺渺一溪水。 汝何不自忍些忧，又却结愤满心头，冰肌玉肤落潭碧，黄昏风惨水空流。 武夷溪九曲，无人垂钩水空流； 武夷三十六峰峦，无人结草惟在山。 月明寻之不知处，尚自哀猿声不住。 那堪一夜潇潇雨，使人吟尽哀惨句。 休休心月君亦贤，人生不死空百年。 掀翻四大惊鱼龙，踏破碧潭深处天。 李白骑鲸去捉月，知章水底眠霜雪。 古人犹自水中逝，皆得水化超生诀。 吾与心月系渠师，来此惨惨烟正飞。 天空水寒千山暗，酌水一酹心含悲。 西风吹此两行生铁汁，去作笛中声又急。 化修造仙掌 一溪横绿，满林幽竹戛琅讦； 两岸环青，匝地苍苔铺翡翠。 乃飞锡登鸾之所，作留云驻鹤之居。 翻盖鸳鸯化现，瑠璃宫殿雕粒。 蝴蝶森罗码瑙垣墙。 相逢皆是神仙中人，必竟会得山林下事。 为人与烟壶高士求翠虚妙悟全集书一幅 即斯时江上，一叶枫向淡云新月之外，状出秋意，山林中人心境两清爽矣。 尝於水云中慕韩景李之久，南风北枝，未之面面。 海南先生言：烟壶高士冲炼太和，白膏盈体，天女散花，道候真净，古熙口与心。 言瀛山道院，闻有翠虚妙悟全集，正在渴中能周旋，此人回否？ 秋气满杖屦，况此六百里清妙溪山。 鞭青牛，迩汗漫，访我於崆峒之问否乎？ 睥睨论金兰，翘首望胎早圆，云鹤一长笑耳。 修真十书武夷集卷之五十一竟 修真十书武夷集卷之五十二

I come to mourn with this verse as Liu Miaoqing entered the waters and departed.
On the Miluo River, the waters gurgle and sigh—
fish and turtles know not the old dragon’s weeping.
In vain do we ply the dragon boat, seeking where?
Why not prepare a single oar from Qu Yuan’s living hand?

By the Wu Hou Temple on the banks of the Great Yu River,
evening sun fills the trees, crows cry out.
Passersby burn paper money here—
why not pour a cup of wine from Wu Zixu’s living days?

Since the deaths of Qu and Wu, the world has grown desolate,
yet their names endure through the ages as if but a single dawn.
By the river, how many shed tears?
Their icy souls and snowy spirits cannot be summoned back.

Alas, the Daoist Liu Xinyue—
his body was poor, his nature fierce.
Though in youth he fell into the wind and dust,
in the end he awakened sharply and cast it all aside.

His heart was noble, yet his name reeked of filth.
One day he died by the banks of the Wuyi Stream,
and with the waters of the Nine-Bend Brook,
washed clean a body heavy with a thousand sorrows and ten thousand hates.

Cao E sought her father’s corpse and drowned herself,
dying as a heroine’s spirit among women.
Liu Cui and Xiao Qiong both perished in the waters—
all that remains is a vast, empty stream.

Why could you not endure a little sorrow,
only to bind your heart with resentment?
Your jade-like flesh sank into the emerald pool,
as the wind howled at dusk and the waters flowed emptily.

The Nine Bends of Wuyi Stream—
none cast their lines, the waters flow in vain.
The thirty-six peaks of Wuyi—
none weave thatched huts, only the mountains remain.

By moonlight, I sought but found no trace,
only the ceaseless cries of mournful apes.
How much worse when a night of pattering rain falls,
forcing one to chant every sorrowful verse.

Enough, enough—Xinyue, you too were wise.
A hundred years of life are empty if one does not die.
Overturning the Four Great Elements, startling fish and dragons,
you trampled the depths of the jade-green pool to shatter the sky.

Li Bai rode a whale to seize the moon,
He Zhizhang slept beneath the waters amid frost and snow.
Even the ancients passed away in the waters—
all mastered the art of transcending life through water.

I, bound to Xinyue as his disciple,
come here as the mist swirls in sorrow.
The sky is vast, the waters cold, a thousand mountains dark—
I pour a libation of water, my heart heavy with grief.

The west wind blows these two streams of molten iron,
turning them into the urgent notes of a flute’s song.

**A Record of Cultivating Immortality and Building the Immortal’s Palm**
A stream stretches green, emerald bamboo rustles in the deep forest;
two banks encircle the blue, jade-green moss carpets the earth.
This is where the flying tin staff alights, where the phoenix mounts,
a dwelling where clouds linger and cranes rest.

Mandarin ducks transform and manifest,
palaces of lapis lazuli carved with grains of rice.
Butterflies array themselves like agate walls.
Those who meet here are all immortals—
in the end, they grasp the affairs of the mountain forests.

For the recluse of the Smoke Pot, a high-minded scholar,
I seek the *Complete Writings on the Marvelous Awakening of Emerald Emptiness*—
a single scroll.

At this moment by the river,
a lone maple leaf drifts beyond the pale clouds and crescent moon,
evoking the essence of autumn.
For the mountain hermit, both heart and landscape are clear and refreshing.

Long have I admired Han Jing and Li in the midst of water and clouds—
south wind and north branch, yet never face to face.
The Master of Hainan said:
The high-minded scholar of the Smoke Pot refines the Great Harmony,
his body brimming with white marrow,
heavenly maidens scatter flowers,
his Dao awaits true purity—
ancient harmony unites mouth and heart.

At the Ying Mountain Daoist Abbey,
I hear of the *Complete Writings on the Marvelous Awakening of Emerald Emptiness*.
Amidst my thirst, he could have aided me—
has this man returned?

Autumn’s chill fills my staff and sandals,
all the more so in these six hundred *li* of pure and wondrous streams and mountains.
Will you whip your blue ox, drawing near the boundless,
to visit me at Kongtong’s gate?

With a sidelong glance, we speak of golden friendship,
craning our necks, we await the early rounding of the embryo.
A cloud-borne crane lets out a long laugh—
and that is all.

*Ten Books on Cultivating Perfection: Wuyi Collection, Scroll Fifty-One* (End)

chunks.original_text: 海南白玉蟾着 怀仙吟 神童往矣，仙佩远矣。 惜乎失话别於交臂之顷，令人不能忘怀。 有激于中，遂作《怀仙吟》，以表区区慕用之诚。 时嘉定八年七月二十七日也。 我怀仙兮神仙侣，霞裾摇曳兮居何所？ 见鹤长吟犹可覆，蓬莱果在半步许。 空留墨宝落人问，字字成行秋雁序。 正心诚意语尤奇，谁识忘形相尔汝。 见鹤吟 午吟三华院，忽有仙鹤十二只玄裳缟衣，飞呜盘舞於其上，因作《见鹤吟》，呈倪梅窗卢副宫。 时七月二十三日也。 纸上画仙挂古壁，朝朝暮暮被烟熏。 泥塑锺离木雕木，不是元皇大道君。 近来尘世无丹诀，哑口道人俱不说。 武夷散人不辱仙，只图一日三埦雪。 白鹤白鹤何方来，丹墀绛阙几时开。 空中莫作嘹唳声，片云冷风何快哉。 鹤作声时我无耳，鹤振羽时我无眼。 蓬来只是半步许，一生且做老担板。 题玉隆宫壁 旌阳归去大康年，石鳌灰寒古洞前。 笑斩白龙横蓼岸，醉骑黄鹤步云天。 金丹玉屑不复得，铁日石函犹宛然。 四十二口家何在，猿啸西山柏树烟。 倪昭卿赋赠叶神童 叶神童弃儒卫从赤松子游，道高德粹，而形骸土木，丰神峻拔，不事修饰，其神仙中人也。 邂逅梼雨来归，深以不及，款陪清高之论为歉敬。 裁斐句寓乡慕之诚，切幸教之。 神童之貌清且奇，神童之道传希夷。 入室三年丹已熟，肌肤绰约光离离。 结缯自覆有余乐，晔晔紫芝堪疗饥。 跳入壶中人莫见，朝游五岳暮瑶池。 有时混世来尘境，短发胡髻满面垂。 顷刻龙蛇生笔下，为将高兴寄新诗。 我疑虚静乐山水，来归旧隐挂冠矮。 愿策浮云飞碧落，致身绛阙长相随。 又 神童天纵何聪明，十幅一息增荣名。 若非唐朝李太白，靖通真人当复生。 击石轰雷惊四座，宝卷拈出安群情。 八卦五行有妙用，金丹大药自然成。 布袖蝙历贱罗绮，银钩婉娩鬼神惊。 仙山便好留仙佩，何必蓬莱顶上行。 忆神童歌 高怀落落如可羁，芳辞岁萝谁摘奇。 我独一览如醉痴，恨不快睹紫芝眉。 望美人兮天一涯，面不相识心相知。 青牛不跨策羡华，金波停饮忘醇酿。 句高耿耿横虹蜕，列星北斗不敢辉。 玄猿号木骥缩蹄，霜鹊孪翼鬼神悲。 天籁自呜非嘘吹，肯与蛙蚓漱污泥。 何当握手谈玄机，蟠桃未熟香难期。 金牌玉字空陆离，碧云馒锁骞林枝。 谪籍尘寰辞玉墀，凡埃俗气非所宜。 世缘未了如沸糜，徒将诧女媒婴儿。 丹霄玉韶何时飞，青鸾久约宴瑶池。 他年骑鹿相追随，玉笋山前同采芝。 跋语 嗟予慕道今几年，检尽丹书要学仙。 铅汞混融无法度，求金交结欠因缘。 抽添徒泥《传道集》，沐浴不解《悟真篇》。 从来玉诀不传注，莫将纸故徒穷研。 半语轻逢至人授，要断江山一回首。 精勤作用有阴阳，反覆短长分前后。 黄婆媒娉岂因脾，金晶飞跃不在肘。 若能夺得天地真，始与天地同长久。 修职郎、新建宁府崇安县尉、翠云子赵汝渠，焚香稽首跋。 修真十书武夷集卷之五十二竟
chunks.translated_text:
White Jade Toad of Hainan’s *Ode to Yearning for Immortals*

The divine lad has departed—
the immortal’s jade pendants, far gone.
Alas, our parting words lost in the fleeting moment of clasped arms,
leaving me unable to forget.

Stirred within, I compose *Ode to Yearning for Immortals*,
to express my humble admiration and sincerity.
On the twenty-seventh day of the seventh month, the eighth year of Jiading.

I yearn for immortals—my divine companions,
their rosy robes swaying—where do they dwell?
To see a crane’s long cry would yet suffice,
for Penglai lies but half a step away.

Yet only their calligraphy lingers among men,
each line of characters like autumn geese in formation.
Their words of sincerity and integrity were wondrous,
who could fathom such formless intimacy?

*Ode to Seeing Cranes*

At midday in the Three Flowers Abbey,
suddenly twelve cranes—black-robed, white-gowned—
soared, cried, and danced above.
Thus I composed *Ode to Seeing Cranes*,
presented to Ni Meichuang and Vice-Palace Lu.
On the twenty-third day of the seventh month.

Immortal paintings on paper hang on ancient walls,
day and night veiled in smoke.
Clay-molded Zhongli, wooden-carved Lü,
are not the Primordial Sovereign of the Great Dao.

In this dusty world, no elixir formulas remain,
the mute Daoists all refuse to speak.
The Scattered Man of Wuyi does not shame the immortals,
he seeks only three bowls of snow each day.

White cranes, white cranes—whence do you come?
When will the cinnabar steps and crimson gates open?
Do not cry out in vain in the empty sky—
how swift the cold wind and drifting clouds!

When the cranes call, I have no ears;
when they spread their wings, I have no eyes.
Penglai is but half a step away,
yet I spend my life as an old porter.

*Inscribed on the Wall of Yulong Abbey*

Master Jingyang departed in the great peace of the Kang era,
the stone turtle’s ashes cold before the ancient cave.
Laughing, he slew the white dragon on the smartweed shore,
drunk, he rode the yellow crane through the clouds.

The golden elixir and jade fragments are no more,
yet the iron sun and stone casket remain.
Where now are his forty-two household members?
Only the apes’ cries on Western Mountain, the smoke of cypress trees.

*Ni Zhaoqing’s Rhapsody Presented to the Divine Lad Ye*

The divine lad Ye abandoned Confucianism to follow Master Red Pine,
his Dao lofty, his virtue pure—
his form like earth and wood,
his spirit towering and unadorned,
truly one among immortals.

By chance, he returned after praying for rain,
and I deeply regretted not keeping pace,
apologizing for my inadequate companionship in his refined discourse.
I craft these verses to convey my longing,
hoping earnestly for his instruction.

The divine lad’s appearance is pure and wondrous,
his Dao transmits the teachings of the Recluse.
After three years in the chamber, his elixir is ripe,
his skin radiant, supple, glowing.

He ties silk to cover himself, content in abundance,
the gleaming purple mushrooms can sate his hunger.
He leaps into the gourd—none see him—
morning he roams the Five Peaks, evening the Jasper Pool.

At times he mingles in the world of dust,
his short hair in a topknot, his beard flowing.
In an instant, dragons and snakes spring from his brush,
his inspiration poured into new poems.

I suspect he delights in the tranquility of mountains and waters,
returning to his old retreat, hanging his cap low.
I wish to ride the floating clouds to the azure vault,
to ascend the crimson gates and follow him forever.

*Again*

How divinely gifted is the divine lad—so wise!
With ten scrolls in a single breath, his fame grows.
Were he not Li Taibai of the Tang,
Jingtong the Perfected would be reborn.

His words strike like thunder from stone, startling all present,
his treasured scrolls soothe the multitudes.
The Eight Trigrams and Five Phases serve his art,
the golden elixir and great medicine form naturally.

His coarse sleeves outshine embroidered silks,
his silver hooks astonish ghosts and gods.
The immortal mountains are fit to retain his jade pendants—
why must he walk atop Penglai’s peak?

*Song of Longing for the Divine Lad*

His noble spirit soars, untethered—
who could restrain him?
His fragrant verses, like trailing vines—who plucks their wonders?
I alone, entranced, am lost in rapture,
regretting I cannot swiftly behold his purple-mushroom brows.

I gaze for the beauty at the edge of the sky,
face unknown, yet heart acquainted.
The blue ox does not cross—how I envy Hua’s bridle,
the golden waves still—his pure wine forgotten.

His lines stand tall, radiant as a rainbow’s molt,
the Dipper and Northern Stars dare not shine.
The black apes howl at the trees, the fine steeds draw back,
the frost-feathered magpies fold their wings—ghosts and gods grieve.

The celestial pipes sound—not by human breath—
how could they mingle with frogs and worms in the filth?
When may we clasp hands and discourse on the mysterious?
The peaches of immortality are not yet ripe, their fragrance elusive.

Golden tablets and jade scripts lie scattered,
green clouds lock the branches of the soaring forest.
Exiled to the dusty world, he departs the jade steps—
the mundane dust and vulgar vapors are not his place.

Worldly ties remain unfinished, like boiling gruel,
vainly he startles the maidens and infants.
When will the jade melodies of the azure heavens take flight?
The green phoenix long promised a feast at the Jasper Pool.

One day, riding deer, we shall follow,
before the Jade Bamboo Mountain, together we’ll gather mushrooms.

*Postscript*

Alas, how many years have I yearned for the Dao,
scouring all elixir texts to learn immortality.
Lead and mercury blend without method,
seeking golden connections lacks karmic affinity.

I toil over *The Transmission of the Dao*,
yet bathing fails to enlighten me to *The Awakening to Reality*.
The jade formulas have never been annotated—
do not waste effort poring over paper relics.

A half-word lightly received from a perfected one’s teaching
demands a single backward glance at rivers and mountains.
Diligence in practice follows yin and yang,
reversing and cycling, distinguishing before and after.

The Yellow Dame’s matchmaking—how could it depend on the spleen?
The golden essence soars—not confined to the elbow.
If one can seize the true essence of heaven and earth,
only then may one endure as long as heaven and earth.

Respectfully inscribed by Zhao Ruqu, Cultivator of Emerald Clouds,
Acting Magistrate of Chong’an County, Jianning Prefecture,
after burning incense and bowing his head.

*Ten Books on Cultivating Perfection: Wuyi Collection, Scroll Fifty-Two* (End)
